class_notes:
(Same as ENVS 344 1)


A study of the relationship between people, the land, plants, animals, and the weather. We will begin with the first European settlements in the New World and study human interactions with forests, horses, and bison. Next, we will study the Industrial Revolution as it transformed ideas about production, pollution, waste, and energy. The second half of the course will be a study of the American environmental movement since World War II, including the questions of clean air and water laws, endangered species, resource depletion, and climate change. Two papers, a midterm and a final.
course_description: History of the relationship between the American people, land, weather, and natural resources, with special attention to the environmental movement since 1960.
